25414012.review:
[h1][u][b]Introduction[/b][/u][/h1]


With the game's story starting off after the events of Re:Birth3, our beloved CPUs, CPU Candidates, and humans return on this installment that showcases three dimensions happening in different timelines namely; Zero, Hyper, and Heart Dimensions.


[h1][u][b]Gameplay[/b][/u][/h1]


In a nutshell, [b][i]Megadimension Neptunia VII[/i][/b] is a compilation of three (3) different episodes: Zero Dimension, Hyper Dimension, and Heart Dimension. 

[i]Zero Dimension[/i] (which is the first one to be played from the three), shows a darker premise compared to the setting of the other games in which is presented in a post-apocalyptic fashion of Gamindustri in which a new goddess, [i]Uzume Tennouboshi, the Orange Heart.[/i]

[i]Hyper Dimension’s[/i] story and setting is very similar to the earlier Re:Birth games and focuses more a new character group called “Gold Third” formed by [i]C-Sha, S-Sha, B-Sha, and K-Sha[/i], and serve as the counterparts of our dear Gamindustri goddesses that also has a transformation similar to HDD referred to as [i]“Gold Form”[/i].

[i]Heart Dimension[/i] focuses more on plot twists which is the result of the combination of both the Zero and Hyper Dimensions, wherein the CPUs travel to a strange, new dimension to find out who is the mastermind of the anomalies happening in other worlds.

The gameplay, compared to the earlier games of the series has also improved. One of those improvements is the [i]"Combo Make"[/i] system, which is somewhat staple in the series. This system helps you customize the attacks that you can use to combo in which the number depends on the current weapon you have equipped on your character (with a maximum of 5). 

In these combos, there are three types of attacks that you can do; [i]"Rush"[/i] attacks, which focuses fast multi-hit strikes, but gives fairly low damage per strike; [i]"Power"[/i] attacks, which hits harder than the other types but has lower number of strikes; and [i]"Strike"[/i] attacks, which is a balanced type in terms of power and strike count.
Another feature on this system is the [i]"Traits"[/i] for each attack type, wherein successfully fulfilling the condition stated on the trait (ex. a standard attack requires you to NOT use a power attack) will bring in more damage output to the performed attack type.

Other gameplay features such as the [i]"Disc Developer" and "Item Development"[/i] similar to the earlier games comes back in this game which serves as a method to make additional equipment or items for your characters. [i]Disc Developer[/i] allows you to create your own original game discs by incorporating "Idea Chips" which has different kinds and varies from levels 1 to 5.Certain combinations can determine if the disc will turn into a [i]"Godly" or "Sucky"[/i] game which offers additional positive or negative bonuses once equipped. 

[i]Item Development[/i], on the other hand, allows you develop items, accessories, and even weapons for your characters to use. In order to make those stuff, you will need to have a [i]"Product Proposal"[/i] which serves as a recipe and will require you to gather ingredients as well as achieving specific Lily Ranks between two characters to produce it.

Not only that, there also other mini-games that you can access (take Neplunker as an example), as well as additional maps and characters unlocked through the DLCs.


[h1][u][b]The Pros[/b][/u][/h1]


    [*][b][i]Quality Art and Audio[/i][/b] - Whenever I play Neptunia games, I always look forward to the soundtracks that I can add to my playlist as well as the "cutesy" and "ecchi" moments described by the artworks presented, both of which are plenty and of quality (and beware, asmost of the art are more revealing compared to the earlier games). High quality standard being kept by IdeaFactory is very much worth of praise.

    [*][b][i]Improved Difficulty Balance[/i][/b] - If you played the earlier games of the series (Hyperdimension 1 to 3), most of them are pretty easy and smooth-sailing in terms of the battle system. However in this rendition, it seems that our daily mobs have learnt some spunk and will give you a hard time especially if you skip most of the enemies and ignore leveling your characters. This is a good adaptation which ups the challenge of the gameplay instead of just hacking enemies in a flash.

    [*][b][i]Tons of Hours in Game Content[/i][/b] - Seperated into three different episodes (Zero, Hyper, and Heart Dimensions), this rendition of the series is arguably the most "content heavy" compared to the earlier Neptunia games. But the game having separate episodes split isn't the only reason why it has more content, the game showcases the comeback of characters from the earlier games (like IF and Compa), as well as some new and interesting characters (like Uzume Tennouboshi and the Gold Third), and also some new features in the gameplay such as the "Combo Make" which adds more flavor to the battle system.


[h1][u][b]The Cons[/b][/u][/h1]


    [*][b][i]Grind Heavy Gameplay[/i][/b] - Due to the gameplay being more of a challenge than the earlier games of the series, this factor will translate into more grind time for players to compensate for the difficulty balancing. Another factor contributing to that is this time, there won't be an EXP boost add-on that could help decrease the grinding, especially in the end-game stages.

    [*][b][i]Reused Assets[/i][/b] - As you progress through the game, you will notice that the enemies and some of the dungeons are somewhat reused with a different arrangement (ex. different color scheme but same model, same maps from the earlier games). While this is something that has been around since the earlier games and isn't something that is of a major downside, it would've been a nice addition especially since the game's theme is about other dimensions.


[h1][u][b]Final Thoughts[/b][/u][/h1]

As usual, Neptunia games are of quality and it's a no-brainer to get for long-time fans, and it is a pretty good RPG to say at the very least for those who are new to the series (and to those who are new, beware of fan-service content overload). 

[b]Rating[/b] - 9.2/10 

[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/elitegives]Elite Giveaways[/url], check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA games.[/quote]

25333175.review:
Megadimension Neptunia V II  (Не 7 а V2)

Це продовження досить популярної серії ігор, про дівчат котрі є "Богинями" своїх націй, а також вони ЦП (центральні процесори) Звучить дивно, але потрібно зіграти щоб розібратись =)
Я не буду вникати в лор світу, для цього існує трилогія Rebirth =)

Що собою представляє ця гра, це суміш JRPG та Графічних новел. Тобто в грі є підземелля з покроковими боями в реальному часі, та маса діалогів у вигляді графічних новел, і такий мікс працює, і не рве враження від гри. І насправді мало за що гру можна покритикувати, але все по порядку.

Тепер трішки детальніше про гру, почати варто з того, що ми отримуємо не одну гру, а одразу три гри (окремих історії, в котрих навіть є частково різні геймплейні моменти), кожна з яких займе не менше 20 годин на проходження, кожна має свій сюжет і наслідки на наступні, і хоча сюжети наче прості, але цікаві, і за рахунок геймплейних моментів дарують різні враження, що вже є безперечно перевагою. В сюжет вникати важко без спойлерів, але це справді на голову вище за попередні ігри серії.

Як я писав вище геймплей складається з двох основних частин, по-перше це покрокові бої в реальному часі, тобто це покрокові бої, але кожен хід ми можемо рухатись по полю бою для використання тактичних маневрів, для прикладу удари в спину наносять набагато більше пошкодження і подібне. Бойова система дуже широка і складається як з комбо ударів котрі покращуються з рівнем і покращенням зброї, так і зі скілів. Але головною родзинкою гри є тимчасові "еволюції" героїнь, в так названий стан HDD, коли вони стають "Богинями" це добавляє статів, та добавляє чи змінює скіли. І про нововведення цих ігор, це величезні бої з босами велетнями, де нам доведеться вибирати навіть устрій команди для оптимальних комбінацій, і також друга стадія еволюції, що звісно дуже круто =)

Графічно гра теж розділена на дві частини, коли ми в підземеллях чи в боях ми в 3Д світі, котрий хоч виглядає непогано, але технічно застарілий, і на жаль багато запозичає з попередніх частин серії, що точно можна занести до мінусів. Але коли ви в діалогах, перед нами 2Д моделі персонажів, дуже високої якості, трішки анімовані, статичні, але проявляють емоції згідно діалогу, ось вони виглядають класно, і навіть трішки покращилась відносно попередніх ігор.

Для мене особисто однією з найсильніших сторін є озвучення серії, я не знаю японської, але просто фанатію від англомовної озвучки персонажів, але на жаль і тут не все так просто. Хоча озвучено дуже багато діалогів, але знову на жаль все ще не всі, тому є куди покращуватись.

В цілому це справді хороша гра, тут величезна кількість контенту, тут справді класні персонажі, котрим приділяється достатньо часу, тут цікаві діалоги в котрих ми знайдемо масу мемів та відсилок на реальні події. І хоча грі є куди розвиватись, для прикладу добавляти з новими частинами, більше нових монстрів, локацій, покращити графічну складову, чи більше уваги приділити озвученю, я все рівно буду рекомендувати цю гру і неважливо чи ви хочете її зіграти ради геймплею, котрий тут глибокий і дуже цікавий. Чи просто ради історії і персонажів, котрі веселі і точно запам'ятаються =)

25297891.review:
[h1] Skippable Disclaimer [/h1] 

[i]Before you head on to read my review I would like to leave this note explaining some things I think are worth mentioning: I have neither played any Neptunia game ever before, (thus this review is meant to be a standalone one , not a comparison to previous titles.) Nor I'm experienced with Novel games as they have never really dragged my interest in the past. (Although in the contrary im familiar with the RPG elements this game provides). 

Despite all that, I had a wonderful time playing through and finishing the game and im most likely going to play around on my NG+ savefile a little bit more. Aside from all this , i've decided to split the review into Short Gameplay Positives and Detailed Gameplay Negatives. The reason behind that is that I feel like there's an overflow of positive self-explanatory stuff over the few actual worth mentioning negative stuff. [/i]

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

Megadimension Neptunia VII is a game that combines the Novel and RPG genre into one , creating a heavily story driven game while adding alot of gameplay elements to keep you interested and curious to see how your characters and the story progress. The game has it's own standalone story although there are many characters that you may be familiar with if you have played the franchise in the past. With the main protagonists being Neptune and her sister Nepgear you'll find yourself in a crazy dimensional hopping adventure, A story broken down into 3 Arcs that on average should take around 40-50 hours to complete assuming you do not skip dialogues and play the game the way its meant to be played. Ontop of that once you're finished you're given the ability to start a NG+ which allows you to try for a different ending, raises difficulty and opens you up to more achievements and challenge hunting.

[h1] Short Gameplay Positives [/h1]
[list]
    [*]The first playthrough alone should offer 40-50 hours of rich storytime and action.
    [*]A great variety in customization for each character including weapons , clothing for both human and HDD forms and accesories.
    [*]Visually, very satisfying both in 3D action and on the Character + Background art during dialogue.
    [*]Alot of treasures/unlockables spread around all dungeons for the players to search for.
    [*]A great ammount of soundtracks and sounds whether you're in a dungeon , listening through the story or moving around in the overall map.
    [*]A great ammount of action-filled unique skills for each character, each with its own crazyness whether its casted directly from them or if it's a formation skill where specific characters gather up to cast an attack together.
    [*]A selection of either Japanese or English Voice-overs to choose from depending on personal preferation.
    [*]Both grindy and casual achievements for players to hunt.
    [*]A big selection of dungeons to play through with many enviromental themes and many different type of monsters.
    [*]After finishing the game, the choise of going for a NG+ which adds more playtime for those interested and those who want to replay the game without having to start from zero.
    [*]Multiple Characters to unlock and choose from despite them not being available on all the parts of the game. (Unless on NG+!)
[/list] 

[h1] Detailed Gameplay Negatives [/h1]
[list]
    [*]The system the developers use on dungeons, while there is a big variety of base themes, is basically recycling a selection of them and changing their layout. While that isn't really a problem I feel like they could improve ALOT on filling out these giant -but at the same time, aside from monsters and few breakable blockable objects such as boxes- EMPTY dungeons. 
    [*]While knowing this is a novel-based game and perhaps the developers wouldn't want to drive that core element away from their game, it would be welcome to see more animated parts on core story moments. It seems that there was an effort  to do that , but it seems like it was executed poorly.
    [*]It bothers me that while theres such a great variety of skills, you cannot interact in any way with them after you've casted them. I would like to see some gameplay elements like: Pressing a certain key on the right time while you're watching the animation of your skill, will cause extra damage or not pressing it at all, will cause it to miss. It doesn't have to be that way for every single skill but it's a real shame when the grinding part gets to you and you basically skip through the animations of skills you've watched multiple times in the past and theres no longer an excitement factor into them. (You can skip watching friendly/enemy attacks or skills with a press of the button if you want to speed up the game)
    [*]Illusionary difficulty: While that shouldn't be something surprising for an RPG , obviously the higher your level is, the easier the game gets. The more underleveled you are, the more grinding you'll have to do. But it seems that there are many stats like Elemental damage and Ele. Resistances that didnt seem to be all that important in the first playthrough/main parts of the game and it seems like raw difference in levels is all it takes to beat the enemy.
[/list]

[h1] Conclussion [/h1] 

I didn't know what to expect when I jumped in. Having the game's pricetag in my head ([i]Note: I recieved the game for free[/i]), I told myself at the beginning that I was going to be a little bit more "harsh/judgemental" than usual but in all honesty I put that feeling aside within the first 3 hours as I was getting sucked into the story more and more. If you like novels or RPGs with a rich story for that matter then I definitely recommend Megadimension Neptunia VII, I had tons of fun playing and in the future Im looking forward to try a new Neptunia title.

25220612.review:
A solid title for all those who praise Nep, but for newcomers, it's not a good entry point into the series.  You can tell that it tries, but this kind of series has way too many references to earlier entries for the 4th game to be anyone's first.  That's right, this is Neptunia "V2", not 7.  Because why not.

Overall, it introduces some good things and some bad things:

+More area variety (not many, but if you've been on the ride this long, it's a welcome addition)
+Combo system redone to require actual thought (can't just set up "powerpowerpower" then "rushrushrush")
+Skill use outside of combat
+A small handful of cg cutscenes
+Better overall quality
+Nepgeardam hat for Nepgear

-No more instant travel, including far, FAR too many world-map random battles that can't be turned off until ng+.  I had to fight normal dogoos twice on the way to the final dungeon.
-tedious scout system in order to discover areas and hidden enemies
-quest system ruined by the sheer amount of quests that depend on scouts finding the enemies beforehand
-party members in the back don't get exp now.  I have 20 party members and only 4 front line spots, Iffy. Why.

At the end of the day, it's more Nep.

25173741.review:
I've you've even partially enjoyed any of the previous Neptunia games then you need to play this one.

The story is their best yet, the music is better than ever, Formation and Coupling skills now actually feel like a part of the game rather than simply tacked on, and the DLC characters actually feel like a part of the world.

Add to that several story elements that are either rare in this series if not straight up unheard of and you've got a recipe for a solid experience all around.

The main story has many twists and turns that I simply did not see coming as well as several moments that reminded me why I keep playing these games time and again.

One thing that I really loved is that after your first run through you get items to make it much faster to get back to the parts you want to play through again without getting stuck with all the drudge work of the first run through.

The music, as I said before, is better than ever. Getting to a serious moment and having the perfect music kick in with flawless timing makes those great moments feel even cooler. Add in the ability to rewatch literally any scene you've seen allows for easier access to those great moments without having to trudge through an entire nother run just to see it.

Seriously, play this game. If you're here reading this then you will probably enjoy it.

Made with the aid of the rhymer website.






62 (ok/good)

TLDR
A fairly bland yet well paced game with minimal grinding needed and lots of dialog.

A hyperdimension game that exceeds all of the other RPG hyperdimension games. But still disappoints, they do not aspire to give the game the dimensions needed to win awards, or impress me. It had a few good moments but many of these fell flat. A game not worth it's 50$ price (I think it's 35$-45$).
It's still in my perspective a mediocre (but improving) JRPG that relies on it's "cutesy" characters and laid back story to sell, this game certainly ain't bad, but compared to other games this game isn't that good. Buy this game if you want a mediocre japanese RPG with cutesy characters and tons of dialog of which only 50% is voiced. (and soft porn)



---------------------STORY

Beginning with story/world, I believed it to be ok, but with a touch of anime "logic" in that in the "dimensions" there are certain rules that if one thinks can predict what is to come, and better foreshadowing; when the mysterious voice talks to some of the characters in the "better off" dimension in a certain way, indeed there is a "guessing game" in the story that is functional and somewhat captivating.
The hyperdimension drivel is still here of course, but this time is injected into scenarios even more out of place than the previous games, almost as if a checklist; whenever there is a big boss battle there is a segment of drivel dialog to lighten things up bafflingly, you can compare with minimal error it to soldiers in a "military shooter" talking about their country's superstars in the seconds prior to combat; literally about an 1 or 2 sentences are committed to it, now I like my drivel, and the overall lightheartedness of the story but there are better ways of transmitting it.

About 95% of the story is done through this animated 2d artwork that is nice and definitely cheap and effective but it leaves me craving, indeed this is a restricting thing that the developers chose to do that does not permit many cinematographic techniques; you will be seeing these 2d artworks doing the talking with little added to make it impactful, I felt they neglected to use other modes of communicating story, probably since it was cheaper this way. The cut-scenes in this game are used mainly to show transitions, and are what I feel is a neglected idea when it comes to varying how the story will be expressed and would be better if these happened more often during the middle of the game, where small cut-scenes would be played to better entertain me, but the current direction of their use is rare when used for story, and is more often as an enhancement to combat as a short improvised cutscene during it, I suspect most of their "cut-scene budget" was spent on the "cut-scene attacks" that you can make your character use.
I recall what I thought was a waste of 3d assets in a fight between the witch and the purple-haired character, where they had an opportunity to have the camera pan on the character's faces as the fight ground down and dialog ensues, instead it quickly reverts back to the 2d stuff.

About 80% of the humor and humor deriving from 4th wall breaking is coming from the dialog with comments like "switching out the protag; Really?" or "here comes a source of EXP and credits" or "UGH, annoying", and incidents with the story dialog, some of it was funny though much of it constrained in the 2d artwork. I really woulda wanted a greater "Range" of topics that can be expressed in the story, like mayhap more depth into some of the sociological impacts of games or I dare say it, something bad about video games (though I  don't think the developers are brave and/or creative enough to bring up a topic in a way that doesn't clash to harshly with the lighthearted story). Minimally there is also a wish of something more significant in this story, to reduce it's "simple/lightheartedness" and to provide more substantial metaphors, such that when I saw one of the baddies and her "delusion power" I thought we had here an opportunity to hint towards the insanity of our modern situation, but to some disappointment it was largely a baddy power, and not really a metaphor for anything. A part of me also wanted more environmental or absurdist humor in it, the kind that "goat simulator" specializes in; like making a level that is a parody of some trope or some "rule" in gaming and then have the characters comment on it, rather than having nearly all of the humor coming from character dialog, of which indeed would have been expensive but I think would expand and improve the humor. However a point against me is that likely, much of the humor is too japanese-specific to be registered by me so thus some of my points are weakened.

Midway through the game they chose to to split up the the 4 main characters up into their own smaller adventure which was nice, since it that let more of their dialog and personalities show through instead of having it to compete with all of the others, though I felt that the good guys were largely the same bunch that one experienced in the last couple of games. Often it felt that there was some absurd luck as if from a cartoon came to twist the fate of the good guys inexplicably, like when another "Goodie" fell from the sky and helped them, or when the witch suddenly is saved by the ninja, or the gullibility of the main character, or the many times the goodies or the baddies get away from danger, all of this reinforces the cartoonly narrative, but I still feel something lacking. This could all be seen as refreshing if you had not played another Jrpg or have been isolated to your own culture, but they became boring to me about 60% into the game, then I preferred to read and rush through the goodie's dialog instead of hearing it, and the only the bad guys (specifically the robots) I listen to (since I wanted to see how they would trash the goodies).

Some of the fun in that midway section came from the peculiar nature of the new rulers of the nations, they didn't really care that much about ruling and weren't about gaining power yet they still had it, and most saw it as on opportunity to live their lives closer to their dreams, indeed 3 of them weren't really in charge of their own societies, content to live in their own ideal life, and the 4th was so relaxed in exercising her powers as to be well "cool" but unfit for ruling. I personally like these kinds of reversals and the "good guys" interacting with them to get back their nations.

Towards the end (optimal ending), I felt the game was inflating it's gameplay a bit, with additional content that didn't feel timely, since clearly the "core reactor" was destroyed and the "ship" was collapsing and yet the characters stayed for an inordinate amount of time fighting bosses and enemies for what felt like 4 dungeons, the story was properly climactic at that time, but I would have preferred that once "core reactor" was destroyed the story dramatically sped up to hurry along to it's end, which I thought would have been an improvement.

Due to my bad word economy and broadness, you must look at the last 28 comments to read the review.

25133253.review:
Megadimension Neptunia, dans la série des Hyperdimension c'est le 4, par rapport aux trois premiers c'est le premier en 1080p, il est beau très beau, les créatures et donjons se renouvellent enfin, l'histoire n'est pas trop mal, il y a trois sortes de fins, même si je considère que la Good Ending n'en est pas une... Le système est très diversifié, on a énormément de choses à faire, il faut aussi avoir du skill avec les deux niveaux Neplunker toutefois avec de l'entraînement et de la patience ça passe.
Passons aux défauts, ils sont très nombreux...
Première chose qu'on remarque, de base si les personnages ne sont pas en combat, ils ne gagnent pas d'exp, sachant qu'au maximum il y a 4 personnages au combat (je ne compte pas les switch ça casse toute progression d'exp) et qu'il n'y a que 2 personnages qui ont un passif qui fait que sans combat ils gagnent quand même de l'exp (qui d'ailleurs est bugué car les personnages n'ont pas besoin d'avoir le lily adéquat pour avoir ce passif), donc pour résumer il n'y a que 6 personnages qui peuvent exp... On est donc obligé de faire des discs pour tous les autres et de mettre Learning, comparé aux trois premiers c'est vraiment un gros défaut, surtout avec 999 levels.
Ensuite on remarque qu'il y a des plans en fonction des villes et qu'il faut tout parcourir pour vérifier à chaque fois si tel ou tel truc est débloquable, avec 6 villes sur 3 plateaux différents, je trouve pas que ça soit vraiment un défaut mais de là à dire que c'est plaisant, je préférais de loin lorsque tout était au même endroit comme dans les anciens jeux.
Ensuite les scouts... dans le 2 et le 3 nous avions Stella, dans le 4 vous avez des pnj qui vont squatter des donjons que vous choisissez, petit truc sympa, vous pouvez même les monter de levels pour qu'ils cherchent mieux mais les objets pour les faire évoluer sont limité à chaque NG+, du coup là même en ayant fait le jeu de base plus 2 NG+ bah j'ai pas tout au max et on a clairement pas envie de tout refaire...
Je passerai rapidement sur le système d'attaque discrète qui est totalement bugué, obligé de rester à côté d'un point de sauvegarde pour ne pas trop y passer de temps.
Les armes, même avec les DLC, c'est pitoyable tellement c'est mal fait, à croire que les mecs qui ont codé ça en avait juste rien à faire des gens qui allaient payer le jeu, histoire que vous vous rendiez compte, les meilleures armes sont ridicules par rapport aux trois premières jeux, mais genre vraiment, du coup vous vous dites que celles des DLC ça sera mieux, bon d'accord oui elles sont mieux, sauf que... Elles rajoutent pas énormément de stats, y'en a bien une qui est correcte, elle donne 10% de plus d'exp, mais la meilleure arme, LA MEILLEURE ARME, elle vous retire 30% de PV à chaque fois que c'est le tour de ce personnage, DU GÉNIE. Ca donne une idée des DLC, cool hein.
Sinon j'ai encore plein de défauts à énumérer mais je vais achever ça en parlant de l'exp.
L'exp, un truc cool, alors pour faire simple, les dlc qui permettent d'aller jusqu'au level 999 sont gratuits, on pourrait penser que tout est fait pour, bah nan, dans ton cul, pour être plus précis, le meilleur mob donne au max 20 millions d'exp (on obtient un bonus d'exp selon le nb de coups donc on peut aller un peu plus loin, 35 millions selon certaines vidéos), à ça il faut rajouter que ce mob est en un seul exemplaire, dans un donjon dans le noir, sans radar et qu'il est au dernier étage d'un donjon, magnifique n'est-ce pas. Mais c'est pas terminé car l'exp des personnages n'est pas comme une courbe logarithme, elle augmente assez rapidement, ce qui fait que lorsque vous avez peiné et que vous êtes vers le level 300 et bah dans certaines situations, un personnage peut ne pas monter de level sur 2 mobs, magnifique. Sinon y'a le colisée pour exp mais alors là... Même des mobs avec la moitié de votre level peut vous déboîter, grandiose.
Voilà j'ai à peu près donné une vision objective du jeu, si vous aimez neptunia et que vous êtes là pour l'histoire, le jeu vous plaira, sinon il vous dégoûtera, moi il me donne qu'une envie, tricher, car en plus je l'ai pas dit mais il y a un event bugué qui donne une CG et qui n'apparaît pas, un bug connu lors de la sortie du jeu sur PS4, il y a apparemment des manips à faire pour essayer de le débloquer mais faire un NG+ non merci.
Sinon pour faire un amalgame, vous prenez le jeu Fairy Fencer F, qui est une merde pas possible pour l'exp car pas optimisé correctement, avec des plans biens chiants, ainsi que le jeu de Noire avec le système de Lily rank qui est le pire que j'ai vu... Vous mélangez tout ça, vous augmentez la difficulté, vous avez Megadimension Victory II. Le jeu est clairement pas optimisé au-delà du lvl 99, les armes sont à chier, on sait pas trop quel perso est vraiment bon car en fonction des situations on a parfois pas accès aux sorts ni aux items lors du colisée.
En somme, ce jeu est à réserver à ceux qui suivent pour l'histoire, elle est cool, le jeu est beau, on regrettera donc juste le WTF des développeurs qui veulent juste pourrir les joueurs, on est là pour jouer, apprécier, pas pour avoir envie de tricher parce qu'on a autre chose à foutre que passer une centaine d'heures à tuer le même mob pour atteindre le level 999. Je le recommande aux joueurs qui ne veulent pas le finir à 100%.

25124824.review:
The only thing that could possibly make this game better is if it had Plutia, so I can see everyone being [strike]abused[/strike] treated very nicely.

Actually though, combat in Victory II requires a little bit more strategy than in Re;Birth with the revamped combo system, and EXE Drive isn't a press to win command anymore. The game isn't particularly challenging, but that said it does take time to 100% like in the other Neptunia games. 

The character writing--though chock full of meta-references, memes, and slapstick comedy as usual--isn't as obnoxious as it was in Re;Birth, which keeps the game just as entertaining without being equally annoying.

The HDD and NEXT Form battle themes as well as the new openings for each of the three parts in the "trilogy" are really, REALLY good. The BGM is fun to listen to.

If you were to get into this series, Megadimension is the place to start. Best product this franchise has produced thus far. Let's see how Se-Ha Girls goes though!

25070089.review:
Grand fan de la saga, j'ai été ravi de voir enfin du changement dans cet épisode. C'est vrai qu'on s'éclate bien sur Re;birth 1, 2 et 3, mais on nous resservait quasiment la même chose (mêmes décors, mêmes donjons, mêmes items, mêmes mécaniques, etc...).
Eh bien là tout a été repensé de presque zéro, on découvre enfin un "nouveau" jeu, avec de nouveaux environnements, de nouvelles features.
Petit bémol pour la map qui fait office de hub : dans les autres opus on pouvait se déplacer librement d'un point à un autre de manière instantanée ; dans VII le personnage doit non seulement se déplacer point par point pour arriver à destination, mais en plus il y a des combats aléatoires (sympa au début, mais très vite sans intérêts) qui nous freine. On met donc souvent plusieurs minutes pour aller d'un bout à l'autre de la map, alors que c'était instantané avant. Heureusement, un item s'ajoute automatiquement dans notre inventaire lors du NG+ et nous permet de désactiver ces combats aléatoires.

Côté histoire, rien à reprocher, c'est dans la ligné des jeux précédents. Si vous avez apprécié les autres épisodes, celui-ci devrait bien évidemment vous plaire (surtout si vous aimez les délires de monde parallèles).

En conclusion, un excellent jeu, toujours dans l'esprit des Neptunia qu'on aime tant.

25017260.review:
[b]Megadimension Neptunia[/b] is an anime RPG with a plethora of various things going on in it that you will gradually unlock as you progress through the game a bit. As far as the story goes, you first get "sucked" into some sort of video game console to another world, and have problems to figure out in that world or dimension. As you make progress with the story, you encounter various challenges and problems to overcome. More stuff seems to unlock as you get to different parts of the game too.

The game contains NUDITY (like the big letters?), and that's probably a good disclaimer for anyone that wants to steer clear of that sort of thing. It's, of course, within the general Steam guidelines for most games, with hair or other things blocking out the full views to keep it from being FULL-FLEDGED NUDITY (couldn't help myself). A little off topic, but I've always wondered about the double standard with NUDITY as opposed to violence and gore, the latter having just about any and everything in this unnatural violent realm tolerated completely, while something more natural in the sexual realm that has to do with the reason people even exist in the first place to be able to censor and filter stuff out... is filtered and censored.  Don't get me wrong, I like both, but only one gets a completely free pass.

Overall, what I've noticed is that the combat system is similar to Re;Birth 1, which is the only one I had a lot of experience in. The combo system is to a certain extent, different than part 1 in a few ways though, since you can set up your combos to work together and have similar traits. If the next move of a combo follows the appropriate rule (trait) when you set it up, it will have a sort of glow around it, letting you know the move is going to hit harder and not miss.  Something I notice as different was the EXE drive, and the way it builds.  It doesn't stay up after you battle and build it, as it did in the first game. It resets after a battle ends. It builds a lot faster though, so maybe not such a bad tradeoff.  Another difference in this game is the random encounters as you travel the "nodes" from one area to another. You can get randomly attacked as you move around. You cannot gain your Life/SP back either on save points, which is another difference.  Only crossing the nodes at towns is it possible to regain health and SP for free, from what I have seen, aside from using items, which isn't exactly free anyway.

Customization in the game is huge! I enjoy all the options you have in town, with scouts, the share system, and development and investment as you progress.  

Speaking of towns, there are a lot of options available once you get far enough into the game.  Investment in three categories: Commerce, Industrial, and Public Relations.  You simply contribute money into the desired category until it levels up. Development is the finding of plans, either through the Industrial investment route or in the game, where you must find materials listed and then fuse or syntesize those materials to get a brand new one.

You can also create discs, which give you bonus attributes.  They can be reformatted as well, and you will be able to keep the old Idea Chips you add to them.  Idea chips are explained in-game a bit. You can create Godly or Sucky discs, which give a bonus effect. Most of them are not as good as what you could create on your own later for certain situations, but some have a nice extra ability.

The scouts are fun to use, and you can send them into dungeons you've already been to or discovered, and they will report back every x amount of minutes based on the dungeon with either items, money, nothing at all, new scouts, new enemies, or discovery of a new dungeon. Had to remove more explanation in depth because of text limit on my review.

Two other things you can do from town are Route Building and Guild. Guild allows you to take on quests, and those are important for raising shares, gaining items or money, or allowing other dialogue to appear in town by picking the Converse tab. Not going into detail with Gallery or Converse, because I am running out of room for my review.


[h1]Pros[/h1]

Battle system is easy to get used to.  If you've played any of the other main games (Re;Birth 1, 2, 3), then this is pretty much the same as those have been, with a few tweaks here and there.

They have individual challenges that are fun to complete.  They can be viewed in library/challenges from the menu to see what all you can do, how much progress you have made, and what you gain for meeting the requirements. You gain small bonuses for completing them with different characters.

Humor in story is nice and light-hearted and keeps everything upbeat. I like how seriously non-serious it tends to be.  Neptune is very naive, and says some really ridiculous things from time to time. Many have certain personalities that can clash or become stronger together depending on the situation.

Large variety of different things to customize, change and/or level up, as I mentioned above.

Controller works well in general, but I had to swap a few buttons out and remap some stuff to have it work for me.  Good now though.

[h1]Cons[/h1]

The music in the dialogue can get very repetitive, but it is a minor gripe since it's fairly low and not the focal point.  It will change based on the mood of the conversation.

Their voices can bother you after a while of hearing them, especially when changing to the menu screen or in fights, since there are only a few things each will say. I would enjoy a deeper amount of commentary upon switching screens and fighting.

The controller stick and pad move way to fast in battles trying to get precise adjustments. It used to be a lot easier to place my attacks in battle right where I wanted them, but the movement speed of the attack area is extremely hard to get right on this one, so it takes me a while sometimes if I want to hit several targets that are more spaced out by just getting the edges of my range to touch each one...

[b]A few issues that might be only related to my own system:[/b]

Music will occasionally "flare up" very loud for a split second upon starting up. Some popping occasionally too, almost the same as the flares, just initially on staring of a new voice or sound.

On the map, there is some delay after the battles end for me. I see the picture freeze for a couple of seconds.

There have been a few small grammatical errors in the text as I was reading along. Someone should hire me to go through all the lines of text and get these kinds of things right, since I pay a lot of attention to detail!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

There are very few things I can really say beyond some of the repetitive sounds that make this game anything less than a spectacular game to play! I would advise playing 1, 2, and 3 first if possible, or start with one of those to see if you like the game series before jumping into this one. If you've already played them and like them, then this is a must have to add to the collection! That said, this is a totally different game in and of itself with simply references to the other games.  You don't have to worry about anything being spoiled from the others if you play this first, from what I can tell so far. Everyone from the other games is sort of explained a bit, so you have a basic idea of who people are, and why they are in the game with Neptune.

The story is kind of silly, but intriguing. So far I am unsure of where it is going, but I'm definitely going to continue playing. Lots of strange and interesting encounters. I highly recommend playing this one, or another from the series!  It's big, and there is a lot to do. You'll be sinking a lot of hours into it if you want to get the most out of your game. 

**[b]I had to cut a lot out of this review due to Steam's 8000 character limit, so it could have been better.[/b]**

Well, time to review this game, huh...
I had a very fun and wild experience with this game. 

Combat mechanics had some new features which were fun to use(You can use heal skills OUTSIDE BATTLES NOW, HOORAY! And Combo trait system was neat.)Giant Battles actually pose no challenge whatsoever but I feel that they will be more challenging in Colloseum
Storyline went even above mk2\RB2 in terms of darkness(bad ending can really show you how much you screwed up if you didn't do the conditions for normal and TRUE end)

New characters had pretty cool personalities(especially K-sha and S-Sha), but where are the rest of Makers? I wolud have loved to see interactions between Tekken and C-sha or Cave and S-sha for example.

But that person who thought that Neplunker was a good idea can go to hell. That thing REALLY FRUSTRATED ME. Everything can kill you if you don't plan your movements. Also that Fog of War labyrinth is really frustrating, too(Maybe I'm bad with directions, who knows)

Graphics improved slightly and new dungeons look really beautiful.
Soundtrack IS REALLY GOOD(especially Giant Battles)! I even recieved a few eargasms!
Also FIRST PLAYABLE MALE WITH BADASS VOICE(if you have the DLC)
In short, it's still the same grind fest that fans love and enjoy.

8/10 For this game from me. And now excuse me while I start a 4-th New Game+ to get everything and beat whole colloseum.

24946317.review:
Po około 60h gry przeszedłem ją i muszę powiedzieć, że jak dla mnie jest to najlepsza część z całej serii Neptunii. Nie przedłużając łatwiej będzie mi po prostu wymienić jej wady i zalety:

Zalety:
-rewelacyjny sestem walki który wymagał zastanowienia się nad tyj jakie combo jest najlepsze dla danej broni, wprowadził pozycjmowanie się bohaterek w celu wyprowadzenia potężnych umiejętności, walki z gigantami w specjalnych streach,
-przyjemny system scoutów dający nam bonusy w dungeonach,
-fenomenalni nowi bohaterowie w tym moja ulubiona postać całej serii czyli Uzume <3 i najlepszy antagonista jakiego spotkałem w serii Neptunii,
-fabuła, która momentami rozbawia przełamując 4-tą ścianę (jakby jeszcze ta istniała), a momentami tak przejmująca, że pojedyncze łzy spływały mi po policzkach,
-nowe dungeony, które w końcu mają na tyle duże rozmiary że można się w nich zgubić :),
-genialny soundtrack świetnie wpasowany w eventy i walki,
wprowadzenie wielu fabularnych innowacji których nie było w poprzednicj grach z tej serii (między innymi delikatny zaryz pierwszego w historii serii romansu).

Wady:
-z początku problematyczne sterowanie za pomocą myszki do którego z czasem idzie się przyzwyczaić,
-sporadychny brak dubbingu (jakiegokolwiek),
-nie podobał mi się tylko system ścieżek, który tylko spowalniał tempo gry zmuszając gracza mającego 80 poziomy pohaterek by ten co chwila walczył z początkowymi potworami,

Podsumowując Megadimension Neptunia VII jest grą wartą swojej ceny i spodoba się każdemu fanowi serii.

24909664.review:
先买了一堆海王星系列决定慢慢玩之后看到这个标题最后面是VII我还以为最新的已经出到7了。。。
还想着看来要有6代要补，所以开始打折的时候没买，真是太可惜了。。。
之后玩了重生123和动作U之后觉得这系列不错，等不及了，直接原价买了这一代还有一些PSV的卡带。

说起来这系列的关系还真是有点乱。。。
重生2、重生3跟VII都还能基本能连上，重生1除了地图跟动作U是一样的之外基本跟别的没什么联系了。
PSV上的激次元组合布兰+涅普迪努VS僵尸军团是女神们为了拯救因少子化而引起的废校危机，决定站出来，成为偶像，哦不，是成为监督，去拍电影拯救学校。
同样是PSV平台的神次元偶像海王星：PP就真的是拯救游戏业界要成为偶像了。
人物是神次元的设定，但是涅普迪努又是生活在神次元的女神，感觉怪怪的。。。
TV版动画倒是重生123都各讲了一点，主要以重生3的剧情为主。

PC的Steam版貌似是美版那边的人弄出来的，所以适应美国人习惯，对白跟日语台词完全不同也不奇怪。虽然3DM这次翻译的还不错，但也毕竟是从英语版翻译的，所以也就那样。这一作PS4是有官方中文，不过官方中文是港版那边的，跟美版那边没啥关系，所以别说官方中文，官方日文短时间PC都没戏。
目前就重生3有找到玩家个人汉化，那个是根据日版来翻译的，比较准确，而且会顺便解释一些NETA。

虽然很多人都说重生3最好，我倒不是那么喜欢重生3，人物印象跟重生1的差距有点大，重生3里超次元那边除了最终BOSS战，基本打个酱油就没了。重生3出地下城不恢复SP，我是很不习惯这一点。重生2主要讲的女神候补生，女神妹妹们的故事，四女神开场就被捆绑Play了，导致很长一段时间没有涅普迪努精心设计的犯二卖萌和IF或诺瓦露的吐槽，以至于我失去很大的动力来打这一代。。。

这次DLC倒是没免费给那么多了，至少不会跟重生2、重生3一样，开场开启DLC之后Nepgear魔剑无双、史书无双了。
这一代总共三篇，刚刚打完零次元篇，怎么说呢。。。
毕竟这一代最初是为PS4定制的，最起码不像之前重生123一样受到诸多PSV机能限制。
立绘感觉不一样果然不是错觉，看来是重画了，立绘的动作也多了很多。
从高处跳下来手柄会震动，新增了道路啊、铺路啊、投资啊什么有的没的。
用Nepgear当队长的时候多了一句“うさぎさんのように！（像兔子先生一样！）”
现在游戏设定就是喜欢弄些什么劫后余生啊什么的，没想到连海王星系列也。。。
开始一看，哦哦哦！新怪物！新地图！
开场对白说好的都是没见过的怪物，然后就冒出一些眼熟的出来充数了。
怪物沿用前作倒是也无所谓，最终幻想啊，勇者斗恶龙啊很多经典RPG的经典怪物确实很经典。
开始我还说这次良心各种新地图，然后直到我进入一个山洞。
诶？这个门口的单行传送门有点眼熟啊，哦，这TM不是重生123跑了多少遍的山洞吗。。。
从重生123一路打过来的地图，一点都没改，差不多闭着眼睛都会走了，这个简直太过分了啊。
BOSS依然还是欧巴桑，这次欧巴桑穿着的是重生1的衣服，变了重生2的最终BOSS，然后被18级的角色吊打。。。

这次新角色不少，大涅普啊、Gold Third 啊、秘密结社啊什么的。
大涅普明明是人类为什么这么强，前作不是说神次元的涅普估计混吃等死自生自灭了吗。。。
还有明明叫做Gold Third为什么会有四个人。。。（四天王一定有五个人定律？）

总体来说还是不错的，玩了前作之后觉得不错的话值得买。

24900492.review: It doesn't matter who you vote for Nep is eternal

24900273.review:
Megadimension Neptunia VII...
This is without a doubt, the best Neptunia game so far in the series. It'll likely take me three days to write this review since there's so much I want to talk about that will make you want to buy this game.
This is the fourth game in the main series and vastly improves so much from previous games, in fact, taking inspiration from other Compile Heart games like Fairy Fencer F.
Combat UI is improved and simplified. Now all your important commands are in a menu when you press Y on the controller (O on Keyboard). Enemies no longer have Guard Points, so you're free to wham them down with any move. However, now movement plays a much bigger role since enemies now have destroyable parts in certain areas (Think Xenoblade Chronicles X). Destroying a part will change the tide of the field and earn you more EXP, Credits, and rare items. Formation Skills are now done by surrounding or pinching the enemy, though be careful of attacks that have knockback or you might mess up your strategy. Movement also plays a major role in Giant Battles, battles where you face colossi in floating platforms that you can jump from one to another making the best use of the new mechanics.
The game also brings back Scouting, the original form of Stella's Dungeon, from the original Victory game, which lets you give boosts in item drop chances, recovery, and change enemies. You can level up your scouts using EnergyMate which lets them scout dungeons longer than normal and have better chances of finding materials, credits, new scouts, and dungeons. With materials, you can develop these items similar to Hyperdevotion Noire and not like the ones in the Re;Birth trilogy. This time they actually give you the end product. Money also plays a big role since now, there's Route Building which lets you build paths to new dungeons, and Investment, which lets you boost shares, and earn new items and development plans (think Xenoblade Chronicles X again, but easier to manage).
If your scout was able to unlock the Neplunker stages, you're treated to a little minigame based on the classic video game, Spelunker. If you've played the original, you control your character in a cave, trying to jump your way carefully from platform to platform, while managing your stamina, and earning speed boosts, and avoiding obstacles like enemies and steam. Just like the original, Neplunker is not easy at all. In fact, some areas are a little too precise and the collision detection is a little dicey. And be careful when you jump, even waist high falls can spell your doom. Make sure you're not using the Jumping Star flag when you're in there. Personally, it's the only thing I don't like in this game, especially if you lose all your lives and you're kicked back to the title screen (unless you're in new game plus, where you get kicked back to the map).
Meanwhile, quests return, and this time, you're now limited to quests of ranking available to you. If you can clear a promotional quest, you get a rank up and can do more quests that way. Quests, as always, reward you with money and items, and also boost shares for select nations. Shares, this time, mean so much. To get what I'm saying, try not to die too often as a CPU or candidate beginning in Episode 2 of this game.
Oh, did I say episode there? Well... this game is divided into three episodes. But don't worry, there's no Episode Pass for you to buy separately. All three episodes make up the ginormous story of Megadimension Neptunia VII. From the dark and gloomy world of Zerodimension, to the cheery world taken over by a mysterious force in Hyperdimension, all the way to an apocalyptic end in Heartdimension, this is a truly big and incredibly well-written story. You'll love the characters, old and new, from Uzume to Big Neptune, and also the tension, the feels, the atmosphere. This is all grandoise.
To accompany all this, new art and graphics show the worlds excellently. The new Visual Novel sprites are a fresh new coat of paint. They have better animations, expressions, and better detail too. Some of the backgrounds are animated too giving the scene life. You'll also love the CGs in this game, especially those with "incredible goods." Graphics are a step up from previous games, and the game offers brand new environments that show that, from the destroyed cities, to sakura parks, and outer space (have fun with Rocket Jump there). 3D models also have brand new animations as well, and are much better to look at too. Some of my favourites include Neptune, Uzume, Nowa, Vert, and Uni (hehe cute handgun pose).
The music is incredible. Even if some of the music comes from older games, the game brings brand new music that's incredible and great to listen to. They are great for each of the situation they fit in. In fact, the music quality is as great as the series's anime adaptation's soundtrack. It's so good that they're even offering the soundtrack in the Digital Deluxe Set so that you can listen to it anytime you want.
In the end, this game, is amazing. It's the best Neptunia game to date so far and fans of the series will love this game so much. Idea Factory and Compile Heart spent a lot of time making this game and they showed Nepu at her finest. This is a monument Compa and Iffy have created, and will be remembered for a long time. Nep it easy!

说实话，我一开始接触海王星系列还只在重生1上，之后就再也没有玩过续作。可当在steam上看到这个游戏正好在搞促销时，为了信仰我毫不犹豫的买了下来。怎么说呢。剧情对于海王星系列来说一直不算是重点，但是这一作的剧情我觉得确实不错，本来打算通过一周目就先暂时搁着，但是剧情的代入感实在太强，不停的吸引着我玩下去，然后玩着玩着奖杯就全部刷完了。

最近前作也开始玩了起来，相比之下，开发商还是下足了功夫，bgm上我个人觉得还是有挺大突破的，（尤其是将军的boss战，所有女神都超次元进化后的bgm真的是燃成渣），但其中又不乏看出游戏商的偷懒，许多的老面孔和旧地图又一遍照搬过来有点略显诚意不足，不过大boss战还是有那么一点来头，新的见闻者系统也是蛮新颖人的的。

相对来说，玩这游戏的大部分人基本都是冲着个信仰去的。但是这款游戏作为日系rpj来讲还是很不错的，剧情也是比较的搞笑轻松向（但结局真的是很感人！）整体游戏难度上也不是特别的简单，推荐给所有喜欢日呆的人。

最后补充一句

求个汉化。。。。=-=

24843605.review:
Upon my first purchase of the game, I was almost tempted to not recommend this game... no, not because the game is bad, if anything that's far from it! This game is a breath of fresh air that I never knew I needed, despite the previous Re:birth series before it being one of my favorite Japanese games by far.
To start, I would like to state that this game REALLY needed fine tuning before being released. I have a NVIDIA GeForce 970 Graphics Card, something that goes above recommended status, so I assumed it would be enough... wrong. For a good chunk of my time, I had to play at such a staggeringly low FPS that it was downright painful to my eyes. So for a while, i left the game alone, assumed Idea Factory wouldn't bother updating it, much like the Naruto Ninja Storm Series, and moved on with my life... boy am I glad to be wrong.
These guys took their customers' gripes about performance issues, and fixed it... already, that's something basic that SO many people in the gaming market neglect to do; listening to your customers is the most important thing. If you can't do that much, then already you're alienating your buyers. They could have taken the easy route and left it as it is, and I am so glad that this is not the case.

24801581.review:
Megadimension Neptunia VII is widely acclaimed as the best title in this little but funny franchise. What I'd like to answer to in this review is if this is true or not: well, my answer is... yes and no. I'll try to explain why.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
You could think that the story is the truly forte of the game but I don't think so and the reason is quite simple. Neptunia is a game based on strong comedy and citationism. Lots of series gave to us an important lesson: to never distort the core of a product is basilar. The story could seems alluring and "cool" to the player because the Zero Dimension arc is well done and it gives a serious and dark tone/start to the game (pretty much as the Mk2). I'm ok with darker stories but only if you can manage to write them and this is not the case. You can really see that the original project was way wider than this. Unfortunately the Heart Dimension is too condensed and the "now cry" situation is elicited in a dull way.
It's clear to me that the guys who wrote the Neptunia's stuff are better with comedy and demential situation. The script was the flattest in the series, full of cliché and unispired dialogues and that's a shame. I'd like to write more thoroughly but I don't want to be boring.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
I really liked the new combat system, now that you have to choose the right abilities and the correct links between them, the game has a new depth but they still need to polish up the skills because in the first part of the game they can make you OP but than they become pretty useless. I'm also happy because now there are more dungeons where the jumps make sense but I can see that the budget it's still low, in fact they recycled more or less 60-70% of the stuff, I think. But I know that they're trying to improve the quality so I'll be not fussy on this.

[h1]Music:[/h1]
Totally loved it! Unfortunately I don't like so much the battle theme, the normal boss theme and the Hyperdimension map theme but the soundtrack is one of the better of the franchise if you ask me. 

[h1]Characters:[/h1]
Here I'll talk only of the new characters. 
Uzume is probably my new best CPU so I don't need to add other things! XD I really liked the Gold Third, they are pretty cool but their first appearance is... stupid. Their role in the story isn't so much better because it's redundant after all if you think about it. But I like the design, the personality and other things about them and they are not useless like the other secondary characters from the other Neptunia games at least so I can connect to a deeper emotional level with them. Nep is love so the more, the merrier. Oh... and Umio is best girl of course lol. Affimojas and Steamax are funny, ok, but the robots from the first Victory were way cooler. Anonydeath, Copypaste... Please guys, there's no match. The "final boss" is poorly portrayed and almost always in an indirect way. I already mentioned the problem in the Heart Dimension, right? Same issue here.

[h1]Longevity:[/h1]
Well, this is the longest game of the series probably and you'll play a lot if you want to obtain all the achievements. If you want to read the true ending on your first walkthrough you'll probably play for 35-45 hours.

[h1]Porting:[/h1]
NOW it's a good porting but if you have Radeon Graphics be aware that you could have problems (for example I had bothers with the shadows and I had to turn them off). And you need a more powerful system to play Megadimension, the game can lag hard with the Next Forms on or against... err... some bosses.

So this is probably the best title of Neptunia, so far. I liked everything more or less but the story is the weak point because it's not the classic style and for me it fails to convey the same feelings that, for example, the first Victory sent successfully to me. I obviously recommend Megadimension Neptunia VII to all of its fans.

Guru Guru Dreams~

24794931.review:
Человечество придумало два слова чтобы описать изменение состояния общества во времени. Прогресс и регресс. Эти слова применимы в аюсолютной любой сфере деятельности общества, будь то технологические изменения или моральные - неважно. Вместо слова регресс возможно использование слова Деградация. 
Собственно, это было небольшое введение, приступим к обзору самой игры, ведь действительно есть что рассказать.
Megadimension Neptunia VII в первую очередь JRPG, а значит некоторую часть времени вам придется бегать и заниматься интересным процессом в котором обычно помогают салфеточки, но если вы обычно этим занимаетесь на hentaiz\org, то советую скачать Cheat Engine и ломануть левел. Поверьте, сюжет этой игры стоит того чтобы не отвлекаться на прокачивание уровня. 
Прогресс, совмещенный с легкой деградацией на лице - именно так я могу описать Megadimension Neptunia VII. С одной стороны мы получили не одну историю, а много историй, очень тесно связанных с друг-другом. Новую музыку, новые локации. Слегка изменные модели и 3д вставки(правда заскриптованные). Новые герои. Принципиально новое передвижение по миру, теперь мы строим дороги и на этих дорогах случаются случайные встречи с монстрами(прям Фоллаут). Карты изменились, стали запутаннее и в целом стали менее коридорными. 
Но вернемся к нашей родной ложке дегтя, локации некоторые так и остались из предыдущих частей, распиаренные новый формы ЦПУ оказались просто мишурой и я их использовал только один раз, да и то чтобы выбить ачивку.
Стало больше фонов на которых героини предстают перед нами частично оголенными.
В принципе на этом все. Надеюсь смогу снять видео, ибо на слабом ноутбуке игра повела себя просто ужасно.

24765963.review:
Megadimension Neptunia VII, one of the best games on the Neptunia series for my opinion. 
This game learns from the past mistakes the Neptunia games had, it makes finally a game that is fully enjoyable gameplay and story.
Even if the game has some downfalls ^^'.

     Pros : 
-The music (duh), finally a Neptunia with new AND great music, The soundtrack is memorable and very good, nothing to say about it.

-The story. Finally a good story that has humor AND tragedy, They finally combined those two to make this, thanks to Neptunia mk2 and Victory they found the way to have both comedy and serious events.

-Uzume, a great character added to the game with a strong story that reflects one of the best consoles ever made.

-The New Game plus is wayyyyy better then before, having access to all sorts of options (Keeping the characters, levels, etc) 

-The enemies. Arfoire isn't the worst character ever now, she's still not taken seriously but there's a reason AND she finally knows how to be a baddie, finally the old hag is competent


     Cons : 
-The map, even if you access a certain item later in the game where you can't find monsters in the map anymore, it's STILL annoying, I've also been unlucky meeting monsters every time, and it's annoying when it had to load the fight and load the map again, i've lost a lot of time with these ^^'. The old Neptunia style was better.

-A bug I encountered (gladly fixed) where my game would play at 5 fps, I had to search deeply in some forums and videos to find the solution, so watch out with some NVidia graphics cards.

-Some DLC are really expensive for the few content they add (not the character ones)

-Another bug (fixed again) where some weapons were invisible and the Metallic Garbacho would be invisible too

-Croire (the biggest douche in the game)


     In conclusion the game is good, the few cons they are are nothing compared to the content of the game, I may have meant that the bugs were annoying but it's still a great game and they are now fixed, it was my experience and I hope you don't have them either, with that said I gladly recommend this game.

24689617.review:
I noticed I have not done a review for this game. I shall now do one like I usually do with previous Nep games! :3

Normally, I would write a chunk in my review but this time, I'll "try" to summarise it overall. Personally, Megadimension Neptunia VII is probably the best installment so far for the series along with RB1 and RB3 as my favourites. I'm actually surprised that despite the minimum requirements, I am able to run this on a Surface Pro 3. However, the newer dungeons, Dark CPU, NEXT Forms and animations for skills/EXEs were rather laggy. Everything else ran suitably enough to play. There are still a bunch of re-used dungeons from previous games but that does not matter. Monsters seem to be different, more variety and some are re-colours. In regards to gameplay, I liked how they tried to make it more challenging in a way such as the one dungeon with no map and only those in battle get EXP which may cause underlevels for some late game. I quite liked the hidden treasures, figurine/card collector achievements. It gives the game a new touch for not being as repetitive. Uniquely, I think they were also added to balance out the grindy achievements such as the good ol' classic lily rank achievements we've been getting the past installments which are much easier to max in VII. I liked the new soundtrack, the CG that is avaiable and reading the events to know more about the characters. One memorable one I'm quite fond of is the matching hats event between Histy and Uzume ^^ Other miscellaneous things I liked were the costumes and accessories, in particular IF and Compa as they finally have another outfit!

Would I nepping recommend this? If you're a nep fan, played a previous nep game then yes. If you're new I'd say, give it a go! Though I'm not sure if you should start with this one. Personally I would say to try RB1 to know what this game is about and it's concept. If not, then start with RB3 ^^

24616419.review:
[i](dieses Review zielt auf ein Publikum welches die Neptunia-Serie bereits kennt)[/i]
Achja... Megadimension Neptunia VII...
Eigentlich mag ich ja die Serie, aber das ist für mich kein Grund hier nun einen Daumen hoch zu geben...

Megadimension Neptunia VII macht einiges gut, einiges besser, aber eben auch einiges falsch.

Diesmal ist in diesem Teil die Musik richtig gut gelungen, auch wenn ich lieber den alten Soundtrack bei EXE Drives bevorzuge... aber nun, gut... kann ich mit leben...

Zum Teil gefällt mir das neue Kampfsystem weil es viel mehr auf Combos gehen soll, ABER... dadurch dass man mit Rush-Angriffen seine EXE-Bar zu schnell auffüllt, endet es in einem Spammen von EXE-Drives und EXE-Farming durch Rush-Angriffen.

Auch ein Teil der neuen Dungeons gefällt mir, wie beispielsweise ein Kirschwald, der gerade in der Zeit der Blühe ist. Kurz gesagt sehen ein Teil der neuen Dungeon echt gut aus und fühlen sich auch Atmosphärisch an. Allerdings ist da auch das krasse Gegenteil bei einem Teil der neuen Dungeon die sich schon wie ein Platzhalter für ein nicht fertig gewordenes Design anfühlen. Ebenso sind viele Dungeons fast 1:1 aus den vorherigen Teilen übernommen worden.

Was mir nun wiederum direkt nicht gefällt ist die Charakterverteilung über die Story, denn im ersten und zweiten Teil der Story kommt man nur selten an eine unglaubliche Zahl von 4 Charakteren in der Nep-party. Dabei hat man bis zu 8 Charaktere die bei Kämpfen direkt und indirekt mitwirken. Juhu... da kommt eine tolle Leere auf...
Wenn ich schon bei den Charakteren bin, viele "alte" Charaktere wie beispielsweise MAGES. , Peashy oder MarvelousAQL, wurden rausgenommen um Platz für neue - für mich unsympatische - Charaktere zu machen. 

Auch für die Katz, ist das Leveling-System. Ähnlich wie bei Fairy Fencer F bekommen grundlegend nur die, die beim Kampf aktiv dabei sind EXP. Das ist bei einer Charakteranzahl wie man sie in Neptunia-Spielen am Ende hat ungünstig. Dann kommt aber auch noch der nonsense hinzu dass ein Teil der Charaktere die passive Fähigkeit "Learning" haben (den Rest dazu kann man sich denken). Ansonsten kann man noch Games im Spiel erstellen die die "Learning" Fähigkeit enthalten, aber dafür gibt es zu wenig Datenträger die den Skill haben können...

Ebenfalls schlecht ist die World-map, bei der man nicht mehr frei zu den Dungeon gehen kann sondern erstmal über Routen sich dorthin bewegen muss und dabei man in viel zu einfache Zufallskämpfe verwickelt wird... fühlt sich insgesamt nach einer Maßnahme an, bei der die Spielzeit gestreckt werden soll. Dadurch zieht sich die Story zu sehr in die Länge und man kann die Lust daran verlieren, Megadimension Neptunia VII weiterspielen zu wollen (so wie ich).

Zuallerletzt wäre da noch das Interface. Ein paar der Änderungen vom optischen her gefallen mir, andere nicht so ganz, ABER in Sachen Funktionalität ist es einen Schritt zurückgegangen. Es ist jetzt aus meiner Sicht wieder auf der Ebene von Re;Birth 1 oder Re;Birth 2. Das Feature Informationen zu Items oder Monstern die man in Quests sammeln bzw. besiegen soll, wurde rausgenommen... und genau das Feature hat mir bei Re;Birth 3 so ziemlich gut gefallen, weil ich nicht mehr auf ein Wiki angewiesen bin / war.

Nun... was soll ich sagen... Megadimension Neptunia VII ist für mich einfach eine Enttäuschung... Ich weiß jetzt auch nicht wirklich wie ich das in Worte fassen soll. Zum Teil vor allem durch das Kampfsystem gefällt es mir, aber dann kommen die unausgefeilten Details hervor die einem den Spielspaß vermasseln. Leider zieht sich dann auch noch in dem Frust die Story auch zu sehr in die Länge, sodass mir jedenfalls im dritten Teil mir die Lust vergangen ist. 
Sollte ich das Spiel im Vergleich zu den Neptunia-Teilen in ein Ranking setzen, ist dieses hier auf dem letzten Platz. Da finde ich selbst das Conquest-Ende aus Re;Birth 2 besser...

24612996.review:
I have to say that this game is good for what it is. This is the first time I have played a game like this before. I have never played the neptunia franchise before, just saw it on my steam recommended list on sale and I decided to give it a try as I was really bored. Boy was I really surprised in a good and bad way.

[h1]Summary for those who do not want to read my wall of text:[/h1]

[b]Optimization:4/10[/b] (I run the game maxed out with DOF and AA turned off at 1080p, It runs ok for my nvidia card which is a 950m (mostly 60fps, lowest 30 fps), but for my amd card which is a R9 290 to drop frames below 30 is just bad. The R9 290 is way more powerful than the 950m, this is unacceptable. Maybe it is the cpu as I have an fx 6300 for my R9 290 but an i7 6700HQ for the 950m. Or it could just be the SSD in my 950m laptop compared to my slow ass HDD in my R9 290 pc. Idk which hardware is causing frame drops the most on my pc hardware but I assume this game has bad optimization for amd cards and maybe even cpus as the cpu they list on the recommended specs does not even has its model number listed and there are no amd cards listed.

[b]3D Graphics: 5/10[/b] (Passable, low quality textures, asset and polygon count, atrocious AA, good quality character models, nice looking enviroment)

[b]3D Animation/Physics: 2/10[/b] (Some really odd animations and the physics is just well, pretty flat. The physics in the game feels very dated)

[b]2D Graphics: 10/10[/b] (Just wow)

[b]2D Animation: 9/10[/b] (Nice breathing, mouth and eye animations, the intros/outros are very well made)

[b]Soundtrack: 9/10[/b] (minus 1 for a few poorly mastered tracks)

[b]Plot/Story: 7/10[/b] (I mostly enjoyed it, slightly overwhelming and kinda cliche and redundant plots at the start. Managed to predict quite a few times what will happen next quite well in the first arc. It took about 40-50 hours for a noob like me with hax)

[b]Girls: 7/10 [/b](All of them are fairly unique from each other, I really like most of the girls, interesting designs. However, some of the girls suck in thier abilites and stats compared to others. Not balanced properly)

[b]Memes/References: 8/10[/b] (Pretty funny memes and references)

[b]DLC: ?/10[/b] (Yup this game has DLC built in and you can buy it if you want. It also has a "free dlc" that you have to manually activate. I have no idea how the DLC changes the gameplay much other than making the game way easier, adding new characters or cosmetic items that don't actually add more playable content for the game. This is not a review for the DLC, I don't own any of them.)

[b]Overall Rating: 7/10[/b] (Highly recommend to anyone new to this series to start on this masterpiece and not play their old games which in my opinion sucks mostly in the graphic and interface department from trying out rebirth 3 on my friend’s laptop. Looking at the other older games interface and graphics on youtube makes me wanna puke too.)


[h1]Now for the wall of text:[/h1]

I was about to rate the game poorly by the shit graphics (3D not 2D), subpar optimization, insane tearing with vsync off, 60fps lock I think, low quality environment textures, awful controls that are meant for controllers and the fact that the keys you bind for the different console buttons in the game do not change at all in the UI. The graphic options are basically shit. AA is terrible (more like a blur filter turned on) DOF that has no point other than to blur the edges of the screen. Basically, I was not impressed with the 3D graphic options.

I'm lucky that I played on a console before and got used to the controls fast once I remembered which keys were bind to the buttons on a controller. I have already put a guide out on steam for on the optimal key bindings for those that do not have a controller and would like to play on a keyboard (you actually don't need a controller; game plays really well on a keyboard surprisingly). Once the issue of controlling the game is out, I have been enjoying the game very much from start to finish. I played the game with them voicing in Japanese because I just feel it’s weird if they speak English (I always prefer sub over dub ye)

The game takes about 40 hours to complete, for a total newb reading up on what to do as recommended by a guide and skipping all the side quests that are not mandatory to continue the main story. The 2D art and UI is top notch, plenty of detail and animation, excellent quality here. The dialogue can be really funny, sad or even disturbing at times. The writing is mostly good, with a few parts that are awkward,cringey or just flat out redundant. The first arc is the worst out of all of them. I would describe the story as sort of watching an anime with 3 seasons in it. All of the 3 seasons are mostly awesome and I keep wanting to know what will happen next. I was slightly overwhelmed when they were explaining the story to me at the start but other than that, I really enjoyed the story. I really liked all of the girls, its hard to select just one.

I really liked the cool (sometimes really funny) skills, EXE skills and formation skills which I feel is the most disappointing compared with the regular and EXE skills. The micromanagement for the skill combo’s, formation and equipping all the weapons, outfits are mildly satisfying. The girls are really cute and cool and this was one of the key factors that kept me going at the start of the game. (You can thank Neptune and Uzume for that). The next gen forms are really cool (other than vert’s hers is well not as developed as the rest) and so are all the characters that you can play as in this game. I’m always wanting to find out what their special skills are and what are the positives and negatives of each girl.

The maps are mostly like typical dungeons you see in typical RPG games, ranging from dark and spooky to colourful and happy dungeons. The monsters just roam around and if you hit them (or they hit you) you initiate a fight. Saving in this game is punishing, (well for someone who is used to saving anytime I want) you can only save after you are out of a dungeon or close to the end of a dungeon. One thing that really annoyed me was the fact that some treasures in a dungeon require you to acquire items to break the boxes blocking your way. The feeling of a stupid treasure stuck there because you can see it but can’t get it is really infuriating. Luckily the guide helped me out and I continued the game without rage quitting.

The soundtrack in this game is just amazing. I never really bothered about most in game soundtracks at but all the ones in this game are really good. No words can say how good it is. Just listen to it yourself. Fits the theme of wherever you are pretty well. The sound design of most of the tracks are excellent. Nice sound staging, you can hear all the different instruments clearly and at different places. Also, neplunker I swear is rage inducing if you did not watch a guide and did the stupidest platforming for 30 mins dying for no reason at all due to bad coding.

I have not finished everything about the game, I just got the true ending (with a lot of raging as I needed to have an extra playthrough as I missed out something, good to see that there was more content in the true ending) and there is quite a bit more content compared to the other endings in the game (bad and good). Only fault I can see here is that the two other endings are lacking and they use the same exact outro video. I feel that they could have done more in making the other two endings more fleshed out and have more reason to go for that ending (especially the bad ending). Other than that, I genuinely enjoyed this game and I would recommend it to anyone new to this kind of genre or franchise.

24578249.review:
Esse Neptunia conseguiu me surpreender do inicio ao fim, ele é bem diferente dos outros em questão de gameplay, parece até mesmo outro jogo, por exemplo em vários lugares você irá precisar pular, nos outros o pulo tava lá de enfeite.A história é meio séria, fiquei até surpreso com a tensão da primeira parte da história, a história desse jogo é a melhor de todos os Neptunia's em minha opinião. A trilha sonora é outro ponto que vale a pena mencionar, é a melhor de todos os Neptunia's.

[h1]Pontos Positivos:[/h1]
+Gameplay bem diferente, os combos contam com um sistema melhor, não basta apenas colocar os golpes mais fortes pra dar um dano alto.
+A melhor história da série.
+Personagens novos são bem legais
+Não é mais tão necessário grindar
+É um bom jogo para quem quer começar a jogar jogos da série, pois coisas que aconteceram nos outros jogos são explicadas.
+Trilha sonora muito boa, algumas música até me arrepiaram.
+O sistema de scouts é como um substituto pra Stella's dungeons dos outros jogos, mas não é irritante e frustrante.
+As dungeons são mais "complexas", grandes e diversificadas.
+A nova transformação das CPU's
+Batalhas contra chefes gigantes.
+Noire e Neptune Adulta > todos os outros personagens.
+Uma vilã com verdadeiros motivos para querer ferrar tudo.
+Piadas e falas que quebram a quarta parede
+Sistema de quebrar partes especifícas de inimigos, é quase o mesmo que o Guard Break só que menos inútil.
+Os Gráficos estão ótimos nas dungeons do próprio jogo
+Todos os inimigos tem vozes

[h1]Pontos Negativos:[/h1]
-O novo mapa é irritante demais, você cria caminhos com pequenas bolinhas até outras dungeons ou cidades, e as vezes andando pra chegar a tal local você acaba entrando em batalha.
-O Depth of Field do jogo é podre, ele embaça o jogo todo praticamente
-O jogo é extremamente desbalanceado no começo, se você entra em uma luta 1vs5 ou 1vs6 se já pode se considerar morto ou gastar vários items de cura.
-Mais uma vez o New Game Plus é meio que um enfeite, os inimigos não ficam mais fortes nem nada, é a mesma coisa que o New Game normal.
-Reutiliza algumas dungeons do Re;Birth 1,2 e 3; Po**a era pra ser o primeiro jogo Neptunia Next-Gen e usa dungeon do "primeiro" jogo?
-Ah esse não pode faltar, seus pais podem achar que é um jogo da Barbie transformer


Esse Neptunia provou que a Idea Factory e outras empresas que contribuem para o jogo não tem medo de continuar lançando outros jogos da série e conseguir manter o padrão de qualidade excelente.
Eu recomendo este jogo para quem é fã da série Neptunia, para quem quer começar a jogar a série, para fãs de anime e para qualquer um que goste de um bom RPG.

A minha nota para este Neptunia é: 9,5

24572985.review:
This part got a lot of new features, not of them are great, but all new things are interesting in it's way, isn't it?
Now lets check pros and cons:

Pros:
+Music edgy af.
+Next forms are awesome.
+A lot of bath scenes.
+Huge story.
+Humor as usual.
+EXE drives looks so sick.
+Spelunker!
+Monsters now make sounds!
+New scout system is much better than Stella's dungeon.
+No barriers anymore.
+New waifus.

Cons:
-Music were great, but voice tracks are horrible. They are sort of creaky and poor quality overall.
-All skills got a huge nerf, now you can easy outdamage them with combos. Now they are only usefull in battles with dark CPUs. And now you have sh!t ton of formation skills and drives with very short (KA-BOOM) cut-in scene (You can't even see your favorite cpu in this).
-Colosseum now is pain in the ass and don't provide any usefull endgame materials/weapons.

24548619.review:
Full disclosure, I've 100% the PS4 version, but haven't played the PC port. 

Aside from some annoying rebalancing of damage, and the gigantic nerf to EXE Drive abilities (which, to be fair they'd be even more OP with how fast the gauge charges and the flag item that grants the never-draining EXE Drive Gauge in NG+), the combat in this game is far superior to the other mainline Neptunia games. Gone are the days of spaming Mega-D Drive and Near Canopus, and in are varied combos and unique strings of attacks. The back line also becomes more useful as using the Switch command no longer counts as an end action, which lets you reach enemies from further away or immediately get access to a more useful character without having to waste a turn. My only other gripe is that Processors got nerfed to the point of pretty much being cosmetic once you get to higher levels.

So what's good about VII? Pretty much everything else. The story is fresh and interesting, with twists and turns that'll keep you playing until the end, and then make you go back because you REALLY want the True End.
